articles.title: ‘Google Maps’ for Roman roads reveals vast extent of ancient network
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 06 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03626-zA high-resolution digital map nearly doubles the known length of the ancient road network.
articles.content:
A data set nearly doubles the known length of roads used during the Roman Empire. Credit: Itiner-e, Artas Media, MINERVA

A high-resolution digital map allows people to plan their routes along the ancient roads of the Roman Empire. Combining historical records with modern mapping techniques, researchers mapped hundreds of thousands of kilometres of roads. The findings nearly double the known length of Roman roads.

The data set was published in Scientific Data on 6 November alongside an online platform called Itiner-e, which study co-author Tom Brughmans calls a “Google Maps for Roman roads”1.

“It’s a growing resource for a community to keep on adding information to to ensure that this remains the best representation of our knowledge of where all the roads in the Roman Empire were,” says Brughmans, an archaeologist at Aarhus University in Denmark.

Brughmans hopes the data set will “revolutionize our understanding of how people, ideas and infectious diseases” spread 2,000 years ago. “Such insights can be used to better understand the challenges we face today,” he adds.

Roman Google Maps

Previous attempts to map the road networks of the Roman Empire had created incomplete data sets with low spatial resolution, and estimations for road locations rather than evidence-based reconstructions.

“Although the roads are one of the best-known aspects of Roman history, it’s surprising how many details about them we still don’t know,” says Catherine Fletcher, a historian at Manchester Metropolitan University in the United Kingdom.

The researchers first identified Roman roads from previous studies, including atlases, surveys, historical sources, archaeological sources and existing milestones. They then compared this information to modern and historical aerial photographs, topographical maps and satellite imagery. The team digitized each road section with a high spatial resolution, then combined the sections into Itiner-e.

The map includes nearly 300,000 kilometres of roads existing in around ad 150, when the empire was at its maximum territorial extent.

Higher spatial analysis allowed the researchers to map 200,000 kilometres of secondary roads. By combining different sources, the researchers could map winding roads crossing difficult terrain with more accuracy, thereby improving on previous estimates based on unrealistic direct lines over, for example, mountain passes.

The data set also reveals that the locations of only 3% of Roman roads are known with certainty. A further 7% are considered hypothetical, because they have been identified but not precisely located or verified across sources. The remaining roads are conjectured and based on fewer documented sources.

“This was a huge surprise and a sobering realization,” says Brughmans. But “that 3% certainty figure isn’t a failure; it’s a ‘call to action’ that gives us a precise confidence map of what we don’t know and where to look next”.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant advancement in historical and archaeological knowledge by nearly doubling the known length of Roman roads through a high-resolution digital map. This resource, dubbed 'Google Maps for Roman roads,' provides a valuable tool for researchers and the public to better understand ancient infrastructure and its impact on historical human movement and disease spread. The project has broad educational and cultural significance, offering a substantial, well-detailed contribution to historical scholarship and public knowledge.
articles.personality_title: New digital map nearly doubles known length of Roman roads
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Roman Empire built a vast network of roads to connect cities and towns across Europe, Asia, and Africa nearly 2,000 years ago. These roads helped people travel, trade, and share ideas. However, until now, historians only had incomplete maps of where these roads were located.

**What happened** – Researchers combined old records with modern technology to create a detailed digital map of Roman roads. Published on November 6, 2025, this new map almost doubles the total length of Roman roads we knew about before. The map, called Itiner-e, works like a “Google Maps” for ancient roads, showing nearly 300,000 kilometers of routes from around the year 150 AD.

**Impact** – This map is important because it gives a clearer picture of how people and goods moved across the Roman Empire. It also helps scientists study how diseases might have spread long ago. The detailed map shows many smaller roads that were missed before and highlights where we still need to find more evidence, since only 3% of road locations are confirmed with certainty.

**What's next step** – The team hopes that more researchers and the public will add information to Itiner-e, improving the map over time. This will help uncover even more details about Roman roads and how ancient societies connected. It may also inspire new studies on history, archaeology, and how ancient networks affected human life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new high-resolution digital map reveals almost twice as many Roman roads as previously known, offering fresh insights into ancient travel and communication.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle carte numérique double presque la longueur connue des routes romaines
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Empire romain a construit un vaste réseau de routes pour relier villes et villages en Europe, en Asie et en Afrique il y a près de 2 000 ans. Ces routes facilitaient les déplacements, le commerce et le partage d'idées. Jusqu'à présent, les cartes des routes romaines étaient incomplètes.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont combiné des archives anciennes avec des technologies modernes pour créer une carte numérique détaillée des routes romaines. Publiée le 6 novembre 2025, cette nouvelle carte double presque la longueur totale des routes romaines connues. La carte, appelée Itiner-e, fonctionne comme un « Google Maps » des routes antiques, montrant près de 300 000 kilomètres de routes datant d'environ 150 après J.-C.

**Impact** – Cette carte est importante car elle donne une image plus claire des déplacements des personnes et des marchandises dans l'Empire romain. Elle aide aussi à comprendre comment les maladies pouvaient se propager à cette époque. La carte révèle de nombreuses petites routes ignorées auparavant et montre aussi où les preuves manquent, puisque seulement 3 % des routes sont confirmées avec certitude.

**Prochaine étape** – L'équipe espère que d'autres chercheurs et le grand public ajouteront des informations à Itiner-e, améliorant ainsi la carte au fil du temps. Cela permettra de découvrir encore plus de détails sur les routes romaines et la façon dont les sociétés antiques étaient connectées. Cela pourrait aussi encourager de nouvelles recherches en histoire et en archéologie.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Une nouvelle carte numérique haute résolution révèle presque deux fois plus de routes romaines que ce qui était connu, offrant de nouvelles informations sur les déplacements et communications antiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo mapa digital casi duplica la longitud conocida de las carreteras romanas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Imperio Romano construyó una gran red de caminos para conectar ciudades y pueblos en Europa, Asia y África hace casi 2,000 años. Estos caminos ayudaban a la gente a viajar, comerciar y compartir ideas. Pero hasta ahora, los mapas de estas carreteras eran incompletos.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores combinaron registros antiguos con tecnología moderna para crear un mapa digital detallado de las carreteras romanas. Publicado el 6 de noviembre de 2025, este nuevo mapa casi duplica la longitud total de las carreteras romanas que se conocían antes. El mapa, llamado Itiner-e, funciona como un “Google Maps” para caminos antiguos, mostrando cerca de 300,000 kilómetros de rutas del año 150 d.C.

**Impacto** – Este mapa es importante porque muestra mejor cómo se movían las personas y las mercancías en el Imperio Romano. También ayuda a entender cómo se podían propagar las enfermedades en esa época. El mapa muestra muchas carreteras secundarias que antes no se conocían y señala dónde aún faltan pruebas, ya que solo el 3 % de las rutas están confirmadas con certeza.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo espera que más investigadores y el público agreguen información a Itiner-e para mejorar el mapa con el tiempo. Esto ayudará a descubrir más detalles sobre las carreteras romanas y cómo se conectaban las sociedades antiguas. También podría inspirar nuevos estudios en historia y arqueología.

**Frase clave** – Un nuevo mapa digital de alta resolución revela casi el doble de carreteras romanas conocidas, ofreciendo nuevas ideas sobre viajes y comunicación en la antigüedad.
